The "SCHIP Expansion Act of 2004" allows all uninsured children to be eligible for SCHIP. The "SCHIP Expansion Act of 2004" allows all uninsured children to be eligible for SCHIP. Section 2110(b) of the Social Security Act is amended to include a child who is an exclusion of children with access to high-cost coverage. Section 2110(b)(3) of the Social Security Act is amended to prohibit the exclusion of children with access to high-cost coverage under a group health plan or health insurance. The Social Security Act is amended to include targeted vulnerable children in group health plans or insurance coverage if costs exceed 5% of the family's income. Amendments also replace "targeted low-income" with "targeted vulnerable" in Titles XIX and XXI. The Social Security Act is amended to include targeted vulnerable children in group health plans or insurance coverage if costs exceed 5% of the family's income. Amendments also replace "targeted low-income" with "targeted vulnerable" in Titles XIX and XXI, particularly with respect to children whose family income exceeds 200 percent of the poverty line. The amendments made by this section take effect on October 1, 2004. Increase in federal financial participation under SCHIP and Medicaid for states with simplified enrollment and renewal procedures for children. The amendment to the Social Security Act allows states with simplified enrollment and renewal procedures to receive increased federal funding under SCHIP. The amendment to the Social Security Act allows states with simplified enrollment and renewal procedures to receive increased federal funding under SCHIP. The amendment to the Social Security Act allows states with simplified enrollment and renewal procedures to receive increased federal funding under SCHIP. The limitation on expenditures for outreach strategies is waived for these states, with an enhanced FMAP increase of 5 percentage points for carrying out the same outreach strategies for children under title XIX. Outreach strategies include presumptive eligibility and 12-month continuous eligibility for children. The State implements 12-month continuous eligibility for children under title XIX and SCHIP, eliminates asset tests for children's eligibility, and allows for passive renewal of assistance. The State allows for passive renewal of children's eligibility for assistance under title XIX and Medicaid if no changes are reported, subject to verification from State databases. The Social Security Act is amended to allow for enhanced Federal medical assistance percentage for outreach strategies targeting individuals under 19 years of age eligible for medical assistance. This applies if the State also implements these strategies for children under title XXI. The Social Security Act allows for enhanced FMAP and increased outreach strategies for individuals under 19 years of age eligible for medical assistance, including presumptive eligibility, 12-month continuous eligibility, elimination of asset test, and passive renewal. These strategies must also be implemented for children under title XXI. The State must not apply an asset test for eligibility under title XXI. Automatic renewal of assistance is provided if no changes are reported, effective October 1, 2004. SEC. 4. ELIMINATION OF SCHIP DIP AND INCREASE IN FUNDING. Amends Section 2104(a) of the Social Security Act to increase funding for SCHIP. Effective date is October 1, 2004.

SEC. 5. LIMITATION ON PAYMENTS TO STATES THAT HAVE AN ENROLLMENT CAP BUT HAVE NOT EXHAUSTED THE STATE'S AVAILABLE ALLOTMENTS. The amendment to Section 2105 of the Social Security Act introduces a limitation on payments to states with enrollment caps that have not fully expended their available funding for child health assistance. The amendment introduces a limitation on payments to states with enrollment caps that have not fully expended their available funding for child health assistance. This amendment does not prohibit states from establishing regular open enrollment periods for applications. The effective date for these amendments is October 1, 2004. The amendment extends Medicaid managed care requirements to SCHIP, effective October 1, 2004.
